awd_titl_txt: Professional Development Supports for Teaching Bioinformatics  through Mobile Learnng
awd_abstract_narration:
Bioinformatics is an emerging area of research that develops new knowledge through computational analysis of vast biological and biomedical data.  This project will investigate the professional development supports needed for teaching bioinformatics at the high school level. Building from a robust literature in professional development design research, project team will work with biology and mathematics teachers to co-design instructional modules to engage students with core bioinformatics concepts and computational literacies, by focusing on local community health issues supported through mobile learning activities. The overarching goal of the project is to help create an engage population of informatics-informed students who are capable of critically analyzing information and able to solve local problems related to their health and well-being. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of instructional innovations. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The project team will use a design-based implementation research approach to identify the curricular and instructional supports needed to achieve the teaching and learning goals through iterative project revisions, employing mixed methods to evaluate teacher and student learning processes and outcomes. Teachers from local high needs schools will participate in a three-week summer workshop, where they will learn about state-of-the-art bioinformatics content, project-based pedagogies that promote computational literacy, and strategies integrate mobile technologies into instruction.  They will implement the instructional units during the year, and the summer workshop will be revised and delivered to an expanded cohort of teachers the following summer. The data collection and analysis conducted on teachers' enactment of these modules will reveal the professional development and implementation areas needed to support particular populations, specifically underrepresented groups in STEM, to engage with bioinformatics learning and take authentic action on local community issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Professional Development Supports for Teaching Bioinformatics through Mobile Learning project aimed to co-construct and field test multidisciplinary high school lessons organized around bioinformatics concepts. This initiative was anchored in culturally meaningful learning, contextualized learning through mobile technologies, real-world inquiry, data literacy, and problem-based learning. Our work focused on four broad research goals: 1) to develop an accessible bioinformatics curriculum and instructional materials that integrate real-world data and STEM practices; 2) to provide high-quality professional development (PD) workshops and support for teachers to implement the curriculum; 3) to improve student learning and participation outcomes through bioinformatics investigations and to support the teaching and learning of data literacy concepts through engagement with relevant local problems; and 4) to foster equitable and collaborative research-practice partnerships among teachers, students, and researchers.


The project developed accessible and affordable sensors to collect data and web applications to analyze data. In addition, we developed highly usable in-person and online PD courses to support teachers in implementing the bioinformatics curriculum. The online PD course was released on the edX MOOC platform, making these tools and courses freely available to educators and students throughout the project’s lifespan. Moreover, we revised the curriculum through multiple iterations with teachers over multiple years.


The project realized several outcomes related to the research goals. First, the PD course was taken by over 25 science teachers and was subsequently implemented in classrooms, reaching more than 1000 students in the northeastern United States. Through multiple published studies the project found that:


1) The bioinformatics curriculum successfully integrated real-world data collection and analysis into high school science lessons, enhancing students' engagement and understanding of STEM practices. The use of mobile technologies and affordable sensors enabled hands-on, inquiry-based learning, making the curriculum accessible and culturally relevant to students’ lives. Additionally, the instructional materials developed and adapted by teachers were effective in anchoring content in real-world exploration enabling active participation in science.


2) Teachers who participated in the PD courses reported a sense of community fostered by interactive components such as discussion boards, synchronous meet-ups, and peer collaboration activities, which were crucial for professional growth and collaboration. Building this sense of community was essential for understanding how to scale the integration of bioinformatics content in high school contexts. In addition, the need for more work with teachers to develop their skills and confidence in data literacy for science instruction, while initially surprising, proved to be an extremely important finding of this study. Moreover, beyond PD, teachers need support in collaborating with their schools and administration to highlight the likely benefits that students will experience through participation in bioinformatics-informed curricula.


3) Teachers' ability to reflect on and modify instructional strategies to better meet students' needs, along with a deeper understanding of the data literacy content, was critical in implementing the bioinformatics curriculum. However, teachers needed additional support in both integrating data analysis tools into their lessons and understanding how to teach with them. Engaging in the development of big ideas for data literacy and subsequently completing content representations for those big ideas supported teachers in developing a better sense of the strategies they were using, the language to describe them, and tools to reflect on them more productively.


4) Students showed significant improvement in data literacy, evidenced by their ability to analyze and interpret complex data sets. The empirical firsthand data collection activities positively impacted students' epistemic emotions, such as curiosity and surprise, which had a generative influence on students' use of epistemic practices, such as taking additional data points, comparing and contrasting hypotheses, and using data to support their scientific claims. Through the lessons, students developed a strong sense of directing their own learning process, feeling empowered to conduct scientific investigations and contribute to problem-solving in their communities.


5) The collaborative approach to curriculum design and implementation strengthened the partnerships among students, teachers, and researchers. These partnerships facilitated the continuous refinement of the curriculum and PD courses, ensuring they were responsive to the needs and contexts of the participants. The project highlighted the importance of trust and mutual respect in research-practice partnerships, which were essential for successful collaboration and knowledge sharing.


Our project has made substantial contributions to the field of educational research and practice. By developing a high-quality bioinformatics curriculum, providing comprehensive PD for teachers, and fostering effective research-practice partnerships, we have promoted equitable and inclusive learning environments for underrepresented students. The findings from our project will continue to inform and improve educational practices, ensuring that students are well-prepared for future STEM careers and capable of making informed decisions about critical societal issues.
